ranked_differential_diagnosis.label: Superior Semicircular Canal Dehiscence (SSCD)
ranked_differential_diagnosis.rationale_short: Consistent with low-frequency air-bone gap, normal tympanometry, autophony, and Tullio's phenomenon; confirmed by CT.

ranked_differential_diagnosis.label: Enlarged Vestibular Aqueduct (EVA)
ranked_differential_diagnosis.rationale_short: Another third-window pathology that can present with similar audiometric findings; ruled out by CT.

ranked_differential_diagnosis.label: Otic capsule deficits (e.g., tumor)
ranked_differential_diagnosis.rationale_short: Less frequent cause of third-window effect; ruled out by CT.

ordered_list.rationale_short: To assess hearing thresholds and identify air-bone gaps.
To evaluate middle ear status and rule out middle ear effusion.
To assess retrocochlear function; elicited vertigo (Tullio's phenomenon).
To visualize the temporal bone and confirm third-window pathology (SSCD).

expected_interpretations_by_visit.collective_interpretation: Audiometry revealed a slight conductive hearing loss at 250 Hz in the right ear (air-bone gap) and slight sensorineural hearing loss in the left ear. Tympanometry was normal bilaterally. A critical finding was the report of vertigo induced by loud sounds during acoustic reflex testing (Tullio's phenomenon), raising suspicion for third-window pathology.

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.result_summary: Right ear: slight conductive loss at 250 Hz (20 dB air-bone gap), normal 500-8000 Hz. Left ear: slight sensorineural hearing loss.

tests.name: Speech audiometry
tests.result_summary: Normal Word Recognition Scores (100%) bilaterally; SRT aligned with PTA.

tests.name: Tympanometry
tests.result_summary: Normal (Type A) bilaterally with normal ear canal volume and static admittance.

tests.name: Acoustic reflexes
tests.result_summary: Present at normal levels; patient reported vertigo during testing at 500 and 1000 Hz (Tullio's phenomenon).

expected_interpretations_by_visit.collective_interpretation: Imaging confirmed the diagnosis of bilateral Superior Semicircular Canal Dehiscence (SSCD), consistent with the clinical presentation and audiometric findings.

tests.name: Other
tests.result_summary: Noncontrast temporal bone CT scan revealed bilateral Superior Semicircular Canal Dehiscence (SSCD). No evidence of EVA or other masses.

proposed_items: Discontinue scuba diving to avoid exacerbating symptoms
Monitor symptoms (surgical intervention not recommended at this time due to mild symptoms)
counseling_actions: Explain the 'third window' mechanism causing the air-bone gap and autophony
Discuss Tullio's phenomenon and its relation to the inner ear defect
Explain that the scuba diving incident likely incited the symptoms by disrupting the thin bony barrier
Advise to follow up if symptoms worsen

escalation.rationale_short: Consultation to confirm diagnosis of SSCD and discuss management options.

follow_up_plan.objective: Monitor for worsening of symptoms which might necessitate surgical intervention.

expected_outcome: Diagnosis of bilateral Superior Semicircular Canal Dehiscence (SSCD) was confirmed by CT scan.
Surgical intervention was not recommended as the risks outweighed the benefits given the mild nature of the symptoms.
Patient was advised to discontinue scuba diving to prevent exacerbation of symptoms.
